comment.author: 26539428@N06
comment._content: My grandfather sailed on the boat to the left known as swastika due to the emblam on the sail. i have a framed photo of the boat that hung in my grandmothers home for years. Obviously the photo vanished for many years after 1939.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/26539428@N06] @nilhopkins - SWASTIKA appears in several of these wonderful old photos.  Best yet (imho) -

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons/7984239401/]

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/26539428@N06] How fantastic! I wonder if your  photograph was taken by the same photographer? According to Robin Elliott's book 'Galloping Ghosts', SWASTIKA was built in 1913 by Charlie Dunn and the first skipper was C. Stewart'. The vessel raced with the SFS.
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] I agree with your humble opinion, lovely photo :)

comment.author: 12354991@N00
comment._content: I wander what's the story on the boat and the symbol.

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/bojanbjelic] Hmm not sure - I suppose it was a very easily recognisable symbol before the war-time connotations. SWASTIKA the 18-footer was launched in 1913 and built by Charlie Dunn. Apparently the swastika emblem was blue on this vessel.
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: Yes, before it's war-time appropriation, the swastika was in wide use as a symbol of goodness and good luck, from lemonade in Denmark - ... to inlaid rubber flooring in the Commonwealth Bank in Sydney and Melbourne - [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet/8490482599/]

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] You can't get much more innocuous than Danish lemonade.
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 12354991@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons] thanks for the response and the references guys!

comment.author: 26539428@N06
comment._content:
Hi all
The swastika has been around for over 3000 years and is used in hindu and buddist religions as well as other civilisations(as good luck charm). Who hasn't been to Bali and not eaten at one of the swastika resteraunts ?. Pity the symbol was adopted by the Nazi party I believe in the 1920's.Thanks for the info on the boat. My grandfather (who worked at garden island dockyards) loved sailing but couldn't swim so an outing on an 18 footer would have been interesting for him.
